byline.contributor: Ismail Khan contributed reporting from Peshawar, Pakistan.
byline.original: By AZAM AHMED and JOSEPH GOLDSTEIN

abstract: Pakistani military and intelligence officials say they are trying to bring about peace talks between Taliban and Afghan government; effort comes after months of outreach by Afghan Pres Ashraf Ghani; talks, if actualized, would represent stark reversal for insurgents as well as first direct peace talks since American-led invasion in 2001.
lead_paragraph: Officials said efforts to engage the group still face major hurdles, including securing the blessing of the Taliban’s reclusive spiritual leader.

headline.main: Pakistanis Try to Nudge Taliban Along the Path to Peace Talks With Kabul
headline.print_headline: Pakistanis Try to Nudge Taliban Along the Path to Peace Talks With Kabul

snippet: Officials said efforts to engage the group still face major hurdles, including securing the blessing of the Taliban’s reclusive spiritual leader.
